title: 105_hr3679
content: AUTHORIZATIONS OF APPROPRIATIONS FOR UNITED STATES CUSTOMS SERVICE AND IMMIGRATION AND NATURALIZATION SERVICE. Authorized appropriations for the United States Customs Service to enhance border investigative resources, anticorruption efforts, combat drug smuggling and money-laundering, process cargo, reduce traffic waiting times, and open all primary lanes during peak hours at certain ports on the Southwest and Northern borders. Authorized appropriations for the United States Customs Service to enhance enforcement and inspection resources on the Southwest land border, investigate anticorruption efforts, combat drug smuggling and money-laundering, process cargo, reduce traffic waiting times, and open all primary lanes during peak hours at major land border ports of entry. Funding allocated as follows: $161,248,584 for fiscal year 1999, $185,751,328 for fiscal year 2000, and necessary sums for each fiscal year thereafter. Authorized appropriations for the Immigration and Naturalization Service for salaries, expenses, and equipment to enhance enforcement at major land border ports of entry on the Southwest and Northern borders of the United States. Funding allocated as follows: $113,604,000 for fiscal year 1999, $121,064,000 for fiscal year 2000, and necessary sums for each fiscal year thereafter. In fiscal year 1999, $48,404,000 is allocated for the United States Customs Service for acquiring narcotics enforcement and cargo processing technology along the Southwest border. This includes $6,000,000 for 8 Vehicle and Container Inspection Systems (VACIS) and $11,000,000 for 5 mobile truck x-rays. In fiscal year 1999, $48,404,000 is allocated for the United States Customs Service for acquiring narcotics enforcement and cargo processing technology along the Southwest border. This includes funding for transmission and backscatter imaging upgrades, fixed-site truck x-rays, pallet x-rays, portable contraband detectors, and contraband detection kits for Southwest border ports. In fiscal year 1999, funding is allocated for acquiring various technology for the United States Customs Service, including ultrasonic container inspection units, automated targeting systems, rapid tire deflator systems, and Portable Treasury Enforcement Communications System terminals for ports. In fiscal year 1999, funding is allocated for acquiring various technology for the United States Customs Service, including ultrasonic container inspection units, automated targeting systems, rapid tire deflator systems, and Portable Treasury Enforcement Communications System terminals for ports. Additionally, $1,000,000 is allocated for 20 remote watch surveillance camera systems at ports with suspicious activities, $1,254,000 for 57 weigh-in-motion sensors at ports with high outbound traffic, and $180,000 for 36 AM radio stations at border crossings. In fiscal year 1999, funding is allocated for various technology for the United States Customs Service, including ultrasonic container inspection units, automated targeting systems, rapid tire deflator systems, and Portable Treasury Enforcement Communications System terminals for ports. Additionally, funding is allocated for different equipment at each border crossing: $1,040,000 for 260 inbound vehicle counters, $950,000 for 38 spotter camera systems, $390,000 for 60 inbound commercial truck transponders, and $1,600,000 for 40 narcotics vapor and particle detectors. In fiscal year 1999, $15,090,000 is allocated for INS for narcotics enforcement and cargo processing technology along the Southwest land border, including acquisition and deployment expenses. This includes detectors and license plate reader software at each port to target inbound vehicles. In fiscal year 1999, $15,090,000 is allocated for INS for narcotics enforcement and cargo processing technology along the Southwest land border, including acquisition and deployment expenses. This includes detectors, license plate reader software, mobile truck x-rays, ultrasonic container inspection units, Portable Treasury Enforcement Communications System (TECS) terminals, and remote watch surveillance camera systems to be distributed to border patrol checkpoints. In fiscal year 1999, $15,090,000 is allocated for INS for narcotics enforcement and cargo processing technology along the Southwest land border, including acquisition and deployment expenses for various surveillance and detection systems at border patrol checkpoints. This includes AM radio stations, spotter camera systems, and narcotics vapor and particle detectors to be distributed to these checkpoints. The Customs Service and INS are allocated specific amounts for equipment maintenance and training in fiscal year 2000 and beyond. The Customs Service receives $4,840,400 for equipment support based on 10% of the equipment cost, while the INS receives funding for various purposes under subparagraphs (B) and (C) of subsection (a)(2). The Immigration and Naturalization Service is allocated $1,509,000 for equipment maintenance and personnel training in fiscal year 2000 and beyond. The Commissioner of Customs may use the funds for equipment other than specified in subsection (b)(1). The Commissioner of Customs may reallocate funds for technologically superior equipment that achieves the same results at a lower cost than specified equipment. The Commissioner of Customs can reallocate up to 10% of specified funds for equipment in subsection (b)(1) to other equipment in the same subsection. The Attorney General has similar authority for funds and equipment in subsection (b)(2). In fiscal years 1999 and 2000, a significant amount of funds will be allocated for increasing inspectors and special agents on the Southwest and Northern borders during peak hours and enhancing investigative resources. In fiscal years 1999 and 2000, funds will be allocated for increasing inspectors and special agents on the Southwest and Northern borders to process cargo and intensify efforts against drug smuggling and money-laundering. In fiscal years 1999 and 2000, funds will be allocated for increasing inspectors and special agents on the Southwest and Northern borders to combat drug smuggling, money-laundering, and corruption. This includes a net increase of 50 positions and additional resources for the Office of Internal Affairs to enhance investigative efforts. The costs incurred due to the personnel increase will also be covered. In 2000, there will be a net increase of 535 inspectors for the Southwest land border and 375 inspectors for the Northern land border. Additionally, there will be a net increase of 100 inspectors and canine enforcement officers for border patrol checkpoints, along with 100 canine enforcement vehicles for the Border Patrol at the Southwest land border. To reduce waiting times at the Southwest land border of the United States, there will be a net increase of 40 intelligence analysts and additional resources for border patrol sectors focusing on major drug distribution centers. Additionally, there will be a net increase of 50 positions and resources for the Office of the Inspector General. The Office of the Inspector General of the Department of Justice will receive resources to enhance investigative efforts for anticorruption, including costs related to personnel hired under this section.
